page.title: 19WILDLIFE
page.content: IN BURRA THERE ARE TWO DIFFERENT KINDS OF SEAL, COMMON AND GREY. THEY ARE EASY TO TELL APART BECAUSE THE GREY SEAL HAS SPOTS ON ITS BACK AND THE HEAD OF THE COMMON SEAL LOOKS A BIT LIKE A DOG. OTTERS ARE VERY SHY CREATURES AND THERE ARE FEW SIGHTINGS. THEY LIVE ON FISH. THE FEMALE USUALLY HAS TWO TO FOUR CUBS. THE FIRST SIGHTING OF RABBITS IN SHETLAND WAS IN BURRA IN 1654. THERE ARE BOTH BROWN AND BLACK RABBITS. THE MICE IN SHETLAND ARE RELATED TO NORWEGIAN MICE AND PROBABLY CAME OVER ON VIKING BOATS. IN THE SEA AROUND BURRA THERE ARE PORPOISES <NEESIKS>, WHALES AND OCCASIONALLY SHARKS ARE CAUGHT BY FISHERMEN. SOMETIMES BATS LAND IN SHETLAND BY MISTAKE, ON THEIR WAY ELSEWHERE.
